instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3330: What is 820-3330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1286: What is A1286? A1286 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2009 , Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2255, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2330, 820-2532, 820-2523, 820-2533, 820-2850, 820-2915, 820-3330..
definitions.Q9706: What is Q9706? Q9706 takes PPBUS_G3H's vltage and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q9706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R9788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q9706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..
definitions.LCD_PWR_EN: What is LCD_PWR_EN? LCD_PWR_EN is a signal that tells the chip that supplies power to the LCD screen to turn on..
definitions.A1278: What is A1278? A1278 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook or Macbook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2254, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2327, 820-2530, 820-2879, 820-2936, 820-3115..
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Chimes and turns on, but no display
threads.message:
Louis, big fan, I appreciate all the content you're putting out for everyone to use.  It's a big help as I venture into motherboard repair.

Would love some help with a 2012 MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B).  It turns on, I hear the chime, but no display:

1) I tried another display - same result, so I'm assuming the issue is at component level.  The board looks great apart from some some dust - no liquid damage or prior work that I can tell.

2) I measured the backlight fuse F9700 (with display connected) - 12.5 volts on both sides.

3) Going down the line <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>, I measured <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> on output (pin 6) - 0 volts.  Would this be the first thing to replace?

4) Diode measure for <RESISTOR>R9789</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R9788</RESISTOR> are .450 and .900.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Chimes and turns on, but no display
threads.message: What do you have on Pin 2 and 3 of the LCD connector. If you don't have 3.3V what do you have on the pins of <CHIP>U9000</CHIP>?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Chimes and turns on, but no display
threads.message:
You don't replace <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> because it is not passing voltage. What if it is not supposed to be? If the voltage on its gate is the same as its source, then it will not output anything, which is normal behavior.

Do you get 3.3v on pin 4 of the LCD connector, or on <SIGNAL>LCD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> on <CHIP>U9000</CHIP>?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Chimes and turns on, but no display
threads.message:
I get 0 volts on pin 2, 3, and 4 on the LCD connector, 0 volts on <SIGNAL>LCD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> on <CHIP>U9000</CHIP>.

Pardon the rookie questions, still learning to reason through a schematic. Next step would be to test wherever <SIGNAL>LCD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> originates?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Chimes and turns on, but no display
threads.message: Pin 4 should have 3V, check L9008. If it fried it fried for a reason, usually shorted LCD cable, so check what caused it.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Chimes and turns on, but no display
threads.message: Thanks for responding.  There is no L9008 on this board - I think that's for the <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> model, but I think I understand what you mean.  The equivalent on this board is L9000, but as I mentioned there's 0 volts going through <CHIP>U9000</CHIP>, so none would reach the inductor L9000.  I'm having trouble figuring out what to jump to next.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Chimes and turns on, but no display
threads.message: Ah indeed. Pin 4 is directly connected to <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> so there must be 3V there or PCB track is broken. Measure on <RESISTOR>R9010</RESISTOR>/11 there should be 3V there too.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Chimes and turns on, but no display
threads.message: 0 voltage on <RESISTOR>R9010</RESISTOR>/11 as well.  I tried checking the whole <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> line, and 0 voltage everywhere.  When I plug the charging cord in, the fans do not spin.  If I plug in the battery, and turn it on, I get the chime, but no display - not sure if that helps the diagnosis.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Chimes and turns on, but no display
threads.message:
No way this thing turns on without <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL>. Check at <TRANSISTOR>Q7830</TRANSISTOR> for <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL>, it must be present somewhere.
It is not turning on on AC because you are using either a fake 85W charger or a non 85W. It MUST be 85W.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Chimes and turns on, but no display
threads.message: Oy, idiot! I'm using a 65W for the 13" - back to the beginning of the thread - thank you.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Chimes and turns on, but no display
threads.message: That will not affect <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL>, as long as there is a battery in there it will power up.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Chimes and turns on, but no display
threads.message: Should it really be 3,3v on <SIGNAL>LCD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> (pin1) on <CHIP>U9000</CHIP>? Maybe if you have display connected???

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Chimes and turns on, but no display
threads.message:
With battery plugged in, I get 3.3V on pin 4 of the LCD connector as you mentioned. I thought maybe prodding everything has cleaned up some kind of minor oxidation. I turn on the laptop, and sure enough, the display works - excellent. I put it back together, but no more display - chimes, blinks for a split second, then black.

Not sure how it's related to the display, but the issue turned out to be the battery indicator cable - I checked this three times. Plug in the battery indicator cable, no more display. Unplug it, display works just fine. I went ahead and replaced the battery indicator cable and board, and sure enough, the display works normally.

Thank you for your insight Louis and dukefawks. Please close this thread.
